image.altText: Alice Springs night curfew

props.synopsis: The NT's police union has advised its members that the government's emergency declaration may be unlawful, after receiving legal advice.

title.children: Police union receives legal advice that Alice Springs youth curfew is unlawful

image.altText: Armani Francois

props.synopsis: The day-to-day lives of children in Alice Springs are being impacted by the town's youth curfew, on the brink of school holidays.

title.children: Armani was stopped by police during curfew while getting a burrito. She says it was 'intimidating'

image.altText: An aerial view of a large newly built house in an estate with an open two car garage and green lawns.

props.synopsis: New data shows landlords are buying every third property that hits the market, as house values continue to grow. Some experts say it's keeping house prices out of reach for young people and first home buyers.

title.children: Investors flood back into housing market as prices rise for 14th straight month

image.altText: A teenager with a brown bob speaks into a megaphone

props.synopsis: When you come of age in Israel, you are expected to serve in the military. But for some young citizens, they have decided to risk the rejection of their families and time in prison rather than join the fight in Gaza.

title.children: When Sofia turned 18, her Israeli military draft showed up. She chose prison instead

image.altText: People crowd around a ruined building as smoke rises from it

props.synopsis: Iran has blamed Israel for the strike that destroyed the consular section of its embassy in Damascus, killing everyone inside including a senior commander.

title.children: Senior commander killed in suspected Israeli air strike on Iranian  consulate in Syria

image.altText: People walking along a street in Tokyo lined with Japanese flags.

props.synopsis: Japan spent years as an economic powerhouse before spending decades under threat from recessions. But seemingly overnight, its fortunes appear to have changed — and it could provide a glimpse into the future for us all.

title.children: Why the sun is rising on a new Japanese dawn

image.altText: A graphic showing a young boy looking up at an illustration of a brain

props.synopsis: The federal government has released a draft of its national autism strategy, which aims to improve life outcomes for autistic Australians.

title.children: Australia is getting a national autism strategy. Here's what we know and why it's needed

image.altText: Dark storm clouds gather over a beach in Victoria as people walk along the sand.

props.synopsis: A cold front moving through Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania is expected to be followed by heavy rain, storms and potentially the first east coast low for 2024.

title.children: Heavy rain and storms tipped for Australia's south-east in wake of ideal Easter weather

image.altText: Group of women do a figure four stretch while facing a mirror in a gym studio.

props.synopsis: Rent rises and cost-of-living pressures have seen more people cancelling their gym memberships. One fitness group thinks making gym sessions tax-deductible will keep more Australians healthy and is lobbying the government to get on board.

title.children: Should you get a tax perk to go to the gym? This group reckons it would help the health system

image.altText: A gurney sits next to an ambulance outside Launceston General Hospital.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's Ombudsman has lambasted the state's health department for its "obstruction" to a patient's request to access their full medical record, urging the Department to "cease this practice immediately".

title.children: Don't sue us: Tasmanian Health Department accused of 'quid pro quo' over a patient's attempt to access their own records

image.altText: A man holds up a brochure saying: "A simple bowel test could save your life."

props.synopsis: Disruptions to health care during the height of the pandemic could be having an impact nearly two years on, with the nation's cancer rates.

title.children: COVID-19 stopped Australians testing for bowel cancer. Here's why we should start again

image.altText: A main street in Camberwell showing pedestrians, cars and a tram.

props.synopsis: The state government has outlined the 10 areas across Melbourne where it wants to collectively build thousands of homes. But data shows it will take some effort to turn around the status quo.

title.children: Melbourne doesn't have enough houses, but the plan to fix it will change Australia's largest city forever

image.altText: Indigenous woman sits on the ground and paints

props.synopsis: Renowned Yolŋu artist Naminapu Maymuru-White has been invited to exhibit at one of the world’s most prestigious international arts events, the Venice Biennale.

title.children: Yolŋu artist who paints the stars headed for bright lights of northern hemisphere

image.altText: A distant shot of people at a medical emergency beside a pool at night.

props.synopsis: Dharmvir Singh, 38, and Gurjinder Singh, 65, from Clyde North were holidaying with family in Surfers Paradise when Dharmvir's two-year-old daughter slipped into the pool.

title.children: Father, grandfather who drowned trying to save 2yo in hotel pool identified as Victorian

image.altText: An illustration depicting vials of red liquid, a man walking with a duffel bag and sheets of paper flying through the air.

props.synopsis: Vials of replica weight loss drugs Ozempic and Mounjaro are being illegally shipped across the world from a house on the outskirts of Sydney.

title.children: Red vials of replica Ozempic are being posted all around the world. The trail leads back to Australia

image.altText: Richard Scolyer

props.synopsis: Professor Richard Scolyer took courageous steps as a cancer researcher, becoming a guinea pig for a radical experiment. And the results could spell the biggest breakthrough in 20 years.

title.children: World-first clinical trials soon to start after 'fantastic' results for Richard Scolyer

image.altText: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon in a car being escorted from court.

props.synopsis: The chair of SA's parole board says it is "concerning" that Snowtown bodies-in-the-barrels accomplice Mark Haydon is being prevented from adjusting to life in the community, despite being granted parole.

title.children: Snowtown accomplice Mark Haydon still in custody despite being granted parole

image.altText: boy in cap with small girl

props.synopsis: A mourning family leans on the community after an Easter holiday outing ends in the tragic death of their teenage son.

title.children: Family 'struggling' following tragic death of 17-year-old at Hastings Point bridge

image.altText: A building with a walkway between two sides destroyed and hanging in the air

props.synopsis: After a two-week raid, the Israeli military withdraws from Gaza's largest hospital, saying it was a successful operation but leaving behind several dead bodies and vast destruction.

title.children: Israeli troops leave Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital a wreck in sea of rubble

image.altText: Tom Hawkins is chaired off the MCG field by Geelong Cats teammates Jeremy Cameron and Mitch Duncan in the rain.

props.synopsis: Geelong celebrates Tom Hawkins's 350th AFL game with a 36-point win over arch-rivals Hawthorn in a sodden Easter Monday clash.

title.children: Cats hold off Hawks in sodden fourth quarter of Tom Hawkins's milestone game at MCG

image.altText: A young woman and man in red and pink shirts with fair skin hold up golden trophies.

props.synopsis: Chloe Mannix-Power and Jack Lacey win the finals of the Stawell Gift after race delays caused by wild weather in the west of the state.

title.children: Stawell Gift delayed by torrential downpour that left almost 12,000 without power across Victoria

image.altText: Parramatta Eels' Clinton Gutherson puts his hands on his hips as he watches his penalty goal miss against the Tigers.

props.synopsis: Off-season recruit Aidan Sezer slots a go-ahead field goal in the last minute against the Eels, with Parramatta captain Clint Gutherson shanking a penalty shot after the siren that would have given his team the win.

title.children: Clint Gutherson misses post-siren penalty as Tigers beat Eels with last-minute field goal

image.altText: A photo of a blonde toddler with a flower behind one ear

props.synopsis: Two-and-a-half-year-old Emile Soleil vanished on July 8 last year while staying with his grandparents in France's Alpine region

title.children: French police find remains of toddler who went missing last year in Alps

image.altText: A graphic illustration of a brain floating in mid air, surrounded by vibrant hues of blue and purple.

props.synopsis: Can you imagine seeing things in your mind? Can you hear an inner voice when you think or read? If not, you might have "deep aphantasia".

title.children: What it's like to have no visual imagination and no inner voice

image.altText: A man standing near his unfinished home

props.synopsis: Steve Yates is just one of many aspiring home owners who have been left in limbo as Victoria's insurance authority deals with a backlog of collapsed builders.

title.children: As Steve visits the site where his family home is meant to sit, his stomach sinks

image.altText: A mother standing outside a home holding her baby and next to her young son

props.synopsis: Government Services Minister Bill Shorten says 3,000 new Service Australia workers will help sort the backlog of claims and relieve long call wait-times, as benefit recipients say the system is too complex and slow.

title.children: Why educated, affluent Australians are unable to navigate the welfare system

image.altText: Joan Baez smiles at the bottom of the stairs at a government building, a large line of police stands at the top.

props.synopsis: The revered folk singer's documentary reveals her toughest relationships and the internal battle she has waged constantly since childhood.

title.children: On the surface, Joan Baez was an icon. Beneath it all, she was living an unbearable struggle

image.altText: Police officers put a person into the back of a divisional van, viewed from helicopter footage.

props.synopsis: Police say three teenagers suspected of conducting home invasions while armed with machetes have been arrested after a high-speed car chase through Melbourne's north-western suburbs.

title.children: Police believe teenagers carried out home invasions armed with machetes before 200 kph car chase in Melbourne

image.altText: A man tries to log in to myGov on a mobile phone.

props.synopsis: The Digital ID bill will establish a voluntary identity verification service, building on the existing myGovID which is already used by 10.5 million Australians to access government services.

title.children: Would you use a government-issued ID to prove your identity online? You may soon have the option

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin chairs a meeting with members of the government

props.synopsis: One of Vladimir Putin's fiercest critics calls on Australia and other Western nations to declare his leadership illegitimate following a Russian presidential election that was widely considered a sham.

title.children: One thing the West can do to make Putin's backers listen

image.altText: a crane with two men working saw into the bridge

props.synopsis: 22 crew members of the ship that collapsed the Baltimore bridge reman on board and crews work to clear debris.

title.children: Crews clear first pieces of Baltimore bridge as ship remains motionless

image.altText: The Tasmania JackJumpers team on a stage in an arena.

props.synopsis: The Tasmania JackJumpers are celebrating their maiden championship title win with fans in Hobart after winning the final game 83-81 in Melbourne on Sunday.

title.children: JackJumpers treated to heroes' welcome following maiden NBL championship victory

image.altText: A little penguin at the zoo.

props.synopsis: Climate change can feel "bigger than just one person … but individuals can do something about this," a CSIRO researcher says.

title.children: New study shows dog attacks threaten to wipe out entire penguin colonies within just a few years

image.altText: A young man with dark hair, a beard, a suit and glasses walks on the street.

props.synopsis: Network Ten applies for a last-minute application to introduce new evidence in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case against the company and its journalist Lisa Wilkinson, just days before the judgement was due to be handed down.

title.children: Network Ten makes eleventh-hour application to introduce new evidence in Bruce Lehrmann defamation case

image.altText: King Charles shakes a woman's hand while walking next to Queen Camilla.

props.synopsis: King Charles makes his first public appearance since announcing his cancer diagnosis alongside Queen Camilla on Easter Sunday.

title.children: 'He is looking very well': King Charles makes first public appearance since announcing cancer diagnosis
